hints.content: Start by identifying the vowels in the string. Remember that the vowels are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', and 'u'. You can create a set of these characters for easy checking.
Next, you'll want to count the frequency of each vowel and consonant. Consider using a dictionary to store each character's frequency as you iterate through the string.
As you count the characters, make sure to differentiate between vowels and consonants. You can check if a character is a vowel using the set you created earlier.
After counting, look for the maximum frequency of vowels. You can initialize a variable to keep track of the highest frequency found while iterating through your frequency dictionary.
Similarly, do the same for consonants. Keep in mind that if there are no consonants, you should set their maximum frequency to 0.
When finding the maximum frequency, consider using a loop to go through the dictionary items. This will help you identify the highest frequency for both vowels and consonants.
Don't forget to handle cases where there are no vowels or no consonants. Make sure your code accounts for these scenarios by initializing maximum frequencies to 0.
Once you have the maximum frequencies for vowels and consonants, simply add them together to get the final result.
Be mindful of edge cases, such as strings containing only vowels or only consonants. Ensure your logic correctly identifies and handles these situations.
Finally, return the sum of the maximum vowel and consonant frequencies. Make sure your return statement is correctly formatted to match the expected output.

questionNotes: The string consists of lowercase English letters only.
If there are no vowels, their frequency is considered 0.
If there are no consonants, their frequency is considered 0.
In case of ties, any vowel or consonant with the maximum frequency can be chosen.
